Yes, the West Point Laboratory for Laser Energetics (WPLE) offers several opportunities for students to get involved in research projects. As a research facility located on the United States Military Academy (USMA) campus, WPLE is particularly focused on encouraging cadets to pursue research in STEM fields and providing them with opportunities to work alongside experienced scientists and engineers.

One way that students can get involved in WPLE research is through the Summer Intern Program. This competitive program offers undergraduate and graduate students the opportunity to conduct research alongside WPLE scientists and engineers over the summer months. Participants work on specific research projects and gain valuable experience in research methods, data analysis, and scientific communication.

WPLE also offers research opportunities for USMA cadets through its Undergraduate Research Program. This program allows cadets to work on research projects in their academic discipline, under the guidance of a WPLE mentor. Some projects may involve hands-on experience with advanced laser systems or other state-of-the-art equipment.

In addition, WPLE collaborates with several universities and other research institutions, providing opportunities for students at these institutions to collaborate with WPLE scientists and engineers on research projects.

Overall, the research opportunities available at WPLE are a great way for students to gain valuable research experience in cutting-edge fields of science and engineering, and to contribute to important scientific advancements.
